This was one of the most efficiently directed Star wars movie after empire strikes back. The fresh portrayal of Luke Skywalker was interesting as it showed how he was in a dillemna. The movie was mainly on character development......Poe learns how to a good leader and take risky decisions while Finn learns that there is a group of people who take advantage of these wars for their own benefit.. the movie also shows what it is to be a rebel t-at sacrificing one\'s life for the greater good is necessary. Iconic scenes such as holdos light speed scene and the snokes room fight was awesome. Mainly the movie shows how the rebellion is struggling to bring Down the first order and how every character is learning from there failures to become better
column19: even master Yoda pops up to lecture Luke...so in one word it was awwwwwwwesome!! '

Dont sip the kool aid on this one. All the praise is from paid critics
column53: brand loyalty hacks who would pay for shit in a bucket if it had a star wars logo on it
column54: or people who just dont understand star wars. The only good thing about this film is the cinematography
column55: everything looks beautiful and incredibly realistic and yet all the immersion is ruined by just how terrible everything else is. Once you refuse to shut off your brain and see past the effects it becomes painfully obvious. The humor here is of thousandfold cringe compared to any attempts made in The Phantom Menace. The film is just that bad that it brings down not only itself but the sequel trilogy as a whole
column56: and furthermore doesn\'t seem consistent with the larger star wars lore or any of the previous films. Jedi training is no longer required and a rookie can now best a master in a scuffle. Luke Skywalker has become so utterly unrecognizable as a character that even Mark Hamill had to express his distaste for this film and referred to his character instead as Jake Skywalker. Yes he retracted his comments
column57: but this was only done at the bidding of his superiors. Some of the only things that stopped the previous film from being a tired rehash of the original 77 film were the interest of Snoke and Rey\'s origins. These points are discarded in the new film as if they were as expendable as a random stormtrooper. Subversion in this film exists only for the sake of subversion
column58: just as everything in this trilogy only seems to exist for its own sake and serve no greater purpose
column59: much unlike the cohesive epic told by the original 6 films. Say what you will about the prequels but they still told an important background to the events of the OT and the lore as a whole. TLJ seems to have been made by contrarian hacks that think they\'re so clever as they laugh and pat themselves on the back all the way to the bank with your hard earned cash. The makers of the film seem to have not watched any of the Star Wars films before the sequel trilogy and don\'t even seemed to have watched the Force Awakens
column60: as this film seems disjointed to it. The new trilogy doesn\'t have that cohesive
column61: planned feel of Lucas\' vision and instead seems like they\'re just winging it as they go
column62:
resulting in what feels like a poor improv and the weakest yet of the 3 trilogies. Episode 9 is still yet to come out but I really dont see them making a comeback from this one.

"People who alter or destroy works of art and our cultural heritage for profit or as an exercise of power are barbarians
column63: and if the laws of the United States continue to condone this behavior
column64: history will surely classify us as a barbaric society. The preservation of our cultural heritage may not seem to be as politically sensitive an issue as "when life begins" or "when it should be appropriately terminated
column65:
but it is important because it goes to the heart of what sets mankind apart. Creative expression is at the core of our humanness. Art is a distinctly human endeavor. We must have respect for it if we are to have any respect for the human race.-George Lucas

What has been done here feels like precisely that
column66: the work of barbarians who seek nothing more than to exercise their power in destroying a cultural heritage loved the world over for many decades
column67: all for the sake of profit. As a lifelong fan of Star Wars since that fateful life changing day 17 years ago when I was only 3 years old and first saw ANH
column68: I never imagined I would live to see the day when the franchise has become such a poor mockery of itself. Perhaps it is just me
column69: but the quote in the film about letting the past die even seems like a subtle jab done in extremely poor taste at those who would reject the new direction. The future is always ripe for the planting of a fresh direction
column70: but for a tree to grow strong it must have strong roots as well. Without the roots
column71: the tree will wither and die. Disney\'s discarding of the EU was one thing
column72: but to turn Luke into a character unrecognizable compared to the OT
column73: along with the futile attempt to rehash it
column74: truly proved once and for all they dont respect the roots. People claim that with time this film will be seen in the same light as The Empire Strikes Back
column75: you will all feel stupid years from now when the hype has died and the film is universally hated
column76: and then you will hypocritically claim to have despised it all along. This move is not only an insult to fans
column77: but also to Mark Hamill and especially Carrie Fisher who deserved a swansong more fitting for a Princess. An utter desecration and vandalization of star wars that feels like a hate letter to all who ever cared for it. I could go on about why this film is terrible but if what I\'ve already said wont convince you then I dont know what will. '

Like many
column114: I have created an account just to review this and honestly this is more of a protest than a review. This movie is a tarnish on a legacy that has already endured the awful prequel trilogy. Star Wars is just a movie to some but to many of us
column115: it represents much more. It is a world of imagination we were introduced to and fell in love with as children and learned to appreciate and cherish as adults. There are many glaring flaws with this movie
column116: as there were in the prequels but what sets this apart is the treatment of the legendary hero Luke Skywalker. Luke deserved a much better ending than this and honestly I will never forgive Disney for this. The opportunity to give a beloved character and actor an epic send-off was squandered here for an edgy dark twist that was not interesting or in line with the Luke we know and love. Mark Hamill did his very best. I wish I could boycott Disney entirely but sadly they are the gatekeepers of much of mainstream creativity and these properties we\'ve grown to love. I wish I could say I will boycott future Star Wars films too and I genuinely would encourage it
column117: but I love this universe so much that I think other directors and writers deserve a chance to give it another go
column118: but I can never support Rian Johnson again. '

Star Wars: The Last Jedi is a disaster. It is not only a complete fail as a Star Wars film in the eyes of a well-versed fan
column121:
but is simply a bad movie in general.
The Force Awakens laid a base for the new trilogy
column124: and a world that looks familiar but feels nothing like the established universe. With the public divided and somewhat unconvinced
column125: the sequel had to expand on its predecessor\'s foundation
column126: shedding light on the questions raised and progressing characters\' storylines in a meaningful fashion
column127:
giving their personalities more dimension. Star Wars: The Last Jedi fails entirely at the tasks at hand.
Apart from The Last Jedi\'s numerous supermassive plot holes
column129: and characters that remain one-dimensional after yet another 2 and a half hours of screen time
column130: the film\'s storyline is zig-zagging from one unnecessary or questionable event to another. As an audience
column131:
all we are left with is to ponder the question "Why?"

The motivation behind the characters\' actions is often left unexplained
column132: giving them a false sense of complexity. The dialogues are unnatural and very much clich\xe9. The bad jokes jump right in the middle of a serious build-up
column135: leaving us completely detached from whatever emotional situation is unrolling on the screen. Significant characters come into the picture and are immediately written off
column136:
leaving us completely unsatisfied.
For a long-time Star Wars fan
column137: The Last Jedi has little to offer other than a few bitter-sweet moments with Luke Skywalker
column139: scavenging off the strong sense of nostalgia. As to the simple visual entertainment
column140:
apart from one or two enjoyable CGI moments there is neither a good ol\' lightsabre duel nor a grand space battle to wow us.
All in all
column141: it is an empty husk of a film under a shiny and money-making label of Star Wars. Good job
column143: I hope you have made your profit. '
